intro.body: The Advanced Encryption Standard is a symmetric block cipher, meaning that it encrypts/decrypts fixed size blocks with only one key. AES Adventure breaks down AES into 3 primary processes: encryption, decryption, and key expansion. Key expansion is the derivation of subkeys from the input key - these subkeys are used by both encryption and decryption. Each of these complex aspects of AES has a simulator in AES Adventure that will walk you through how AES operates on your input. AES Adventure supports all 3 key sizes used by AES: 128, 192 and 256 bits. Note: all data in AES Adventure is represented in hexadecimal; 1 hexadecimal digit is 4 bits = 1 nibble = 0.5 bytes.

animations.body: All of the simulators use animations to clearly show each step of the process. These animations support play, pause and seek operations. The playback speed of all animations can be doubled or halved using the rabbit and turtle icons respectively. Each step will have a button to move on to the next step - if you are learning the step, it is recommended that you do not move on until the button becomes highlighed (which generally occurs near the end of the animation).

tutorials.body: All of the simulators have Tutorial icons scattered throughout. To get a textual explanation of what the icon is beside, click the tutorial icon to expand the simulator sidebar and reveal the corresponding tutorial. The sidebar will automatically return to the original size by clicking the same tutorial icon or moving on to the next step. Alternatively, the sidebar width can be manually adjusted using the dragging handle in the bottom right.

configuration.body: The encryption and decryption simulators support a limited set of configurations that can be used by more advanced users to experiment with AES. These configurations can be found in the Configure modal to the left of this page. Note: changing the configuration will reset all simulators.

persistence.body: The entire state of AES Adventure is saved to your browser's localstorage with keys that begin with 'AES_ADVENTURE_UI__'. This means that if you close or leave AES Adventure, any simulations that are currently running will be completely restored when you return. If, for whatever reason, the application enters a broken state, it can be hard reset by deleting it's data in localstorage and refreshing the page.

duplicate-buttons.body: When an input area is full, you will see 1 or 2 copy icon buttons. The first button is a standard copy-to-clipboard button. The second one has a special ease-of-use function depending on which input it is beneath. Under the 'Ciphertext' output of encryption: copies the ciphertext over to the input of the decryption simulator. Under the 'Plaintext' output of decryption: copies the plaintext over to the input of the encryption simulator. Under any key input: copies the key into all other simulators - this is particularly useful to quickly use the same key for encryption, decryption and key expansion. Note: if the copy operation modifies input, the target simulator will be reset as inputs cannot be changed mid-simulation.

i18n.body: The language of the entire app can be changed in 'Settings'. These translations are expected to be imperfect; we did not hire professional translators to do this translation. Soon, there will be a way for you to request a fix/correction to the language files that store all of the translations.

quick-points.cant-input: Input data cannot be changed if a simulator is currently using it. Hit the 'Reset' button to exit the current simulation and you will be able to modify the inputs once more.
quick-points.cant-start: Simulators cannot be started until all required input areas are filled. All input areas will have a 'nibbles remaining' counter below them.
quick-points.nibble: 1 nibble is half a byte of course! (Also equivalent to 1 hexadecimal digit)
quick-points.small: AES Adventure is designed to be viewed through screens that are atleast 13" in size. This is the smallest standard laptop size, which we expect all our users to be equipped with. If you find yourself with something smaller, utilize the browser's zoom capabilities and zoom out. If you are on mobile, rotate the device into landscape mode to get as much additional width as possible.

plaintext-to-state.body: The first step is to create the state matrix that will be operated on throughout the encryption process. The plaintext is arranged into a 4x4 matrix of bytes and then this matrix is transposed.

ciphertext-to-state.body: The first step is to create the state matrix that will be operated on throughout the decryption process. The ciphertext is arranged into a 4x4 matrix of bytes and then this matrix is transposed.

key-to-state.body: The first step is to create the state vector that will be appended to throughout the key expansion process. The key is arranged into a vector of words, where 1 word is 4 bytes. The AES key schedule changes slightly with each key size, but it is always word-oriented.

add-key.body: The key is XORed with the state matrix. Note that the key is also arranged into a 4x4 matrix of bytes and transposed, just like the input. This is also referred to as key whitening.

add-round-key.body: The round key is XORed with the state matrix. Note that the round key is also arranged into a 4x4 matrix of bytes and transposed. Head over to the Key Expansion tab to learn how these round keys are created. During encryption, the round keys are used in the order they are created. During decryption, the round keys are used in the opposite order.

add-words.body: The first word is XORed with the last word, after the Round ùëî-function has been invoked on it. From there, each word is XORed with the previously computed word to create a new word which is then appended to the state vector. The 256-bit key schedule invokes the Round ‚Ñé-function on the 4th word generated in the round before continuing as normal.
add-words.note: The ùëî-function and ‚Ñé-function computations are outlined in the following round steps.

round-g-fn.body: The ùëî-function consists of a series of operations on the bytes of the input word: Substitute Bytes, Shift Rows (shift = 1), and the first byte is XORed with the round constant. The bytes are then concatenated to form the output word.

round-h-fn.body: The ‚Ñé-function consists of a Substitute Bytes on the bytes of the input word. The bytes are then concatenated to form the output word.

round-keys.body: These subkeys are taken in the order shown during encryption. During decryption, they are used in the opposite order.

rounds-header.body: AES operates on the state matrix in rounds. 10 rounds for a key size of 128 bits, 12 rounds for 192 bits, and 14 rounds for 256 bits. Each round consists of the steps Substitute Bytes, Shift Rows, Mix Columns, Add Round Key; except for the final round, which does not include Mix Columns. During decryption, the steps are executed in the opposite order and Mix Columns is not included in the first round.

key-rounds-header.body: Each round of AES needs a subkey, plus 1 for key whitening. 11 subkeys for a key size of 128 bits, 13 subkeys for 192 bits, and 15 subkeys for 256 bits. Each round operates on the previous round's output to derive new words.
key-rounds-header.aes-a: AES Adventure breaks down each round into Add Words, Round ùëî-function and Round ‚Ñé-function steps. Only the 256-bit key schedule uses the Round ‚Ñé-function step in each round, except for the final round.
key-rounds-header.note: Each round generates 1 subkey for a key size of 128 bits, 1.5 subkeys for 192 bits, and 2 subkeys for 256 bits, except the final round which generates 1 subkey for all three key sizes.

rounds-stats.diffusion:
Diffusion is the influence of a single plaintext bit on the (current) ciphertext. The metric is represented in AES Adventure by the avalanche effect. This is calculated as follows: for each plaintext bit, flip it and compute the (current) ciphertext with the modified plaintext. Then, count the number of bits flipped in the (current) ciphertext: the metric is the average number of bits flipped across all plaintext variations.
Shift Rows and Mix Columns may be collectively referred to as the diffusion layer because they are the major diffusive steps in AES.
rounds-stats.confusion:
Confusion is the relationship between the (current) ciphertext and the key. The metric is represented in AES Adventure by a measure of association between the (current) ciphertext and key in which all 0s have been mapped to -1s.
Substitute Bytes introduces confusion in AES.

sub-bytes.body: Substitute Bytes replaces each state matrix byte with a byte from the substitution box, which provides non-linearity in AES (protection against analytical attacks). It is a bijective mapping; during decryption, we use the unique inverse of the substitution box.

shift-rows.body: Shift Rows performs a byte-wise cyclic shift on each row of the state matrix. During decryption, the shift is in the opposite direction. In both cases, the shift on the first row is 0, meaning the first row is never affected.

mix-columns.body: Mix Columns multiplies each column vector of the state matrix by a matrix of constants to produce the corresponding column of the resulting state matrix. The constant matrix is invertible; during decryption, we use the unique inverse of the constant matrix.

state-to-ciphertext.body: The final step is to create the ciphertext that is the output of the encryption process. The state matrix is transposed and then each entry is concatenated.

state-to-plaintext.body: The final step is to create the plaintext that is the output of the decryption process. The state matrix is transposed and then each entry is concatenated.

state-to-round-keys.body: The final step is to create the round keys that are the output of the key expansion process. The state vector words are taken 4 at a time and then each group is concatenated to form a subkey.
